intro: Sisyrinchium graminifolium var. maculatum, commonly known as the spotted blue-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Iridaceae family and is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and small, showy blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky soils. It produces a cluster of flowers at the tip of each stem, which bloom in early summer. The varietal name "maculatum" refers to the distinctive spotted markings on its leaves, which add to its ornamental appeal.
